Sullivan v. Boston & Albany R.R. Co., 20.raw_text: Sullivan v. Boston & Albany R.R. Co., 202 Mass. 41 (1909) (duty of care and proximate cause principles).
Sullivan v. Boston & Albany R.R. Co., 20.proposition: Sullivan v. Boston & Albany R.R. Co., 202 Mass. 41 (1909) (duty of care and proximate cause principles).
Sullivan v. Boston & Albany R.R. Co., 20.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns interpretation and duration of a contractual dividend guaranty in a stock repurchase agreement, not tort duties of care or proximate cause. The court analyzes how long the guaranty runs (one year vs. reasonable time) and treats it as collateral to an agreement to repurchase, but nowhere discusses negligence, duty of care, or proximate cause principles. Thus, citing this case for duty of care and proximate cause is inaccurate.
Sullivan v. Boston & Albany R.R. Co., 20.relevant_excerpt: "The case is not free from difficulty, but we think that the ruling was right. The guaranty admits of several constructions,— either that the dividends were to be paid as long as the plaintiff held the stock, or during the life of the corporation, or for a reasonable time, or for the year to which the obligation to repurchase was limited. ... We regard the guaranty rather as collateral to the agreement to purchase and repurchase than as an independent and separate agreement."

Lopes v. Barber, 374 Mass. 293 (1978) (d.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lopes v. Barber is a criminal case about arson and first-degree murder arising from a hotel fire, focusing on sufficiency of the evidence, mistrial, impeachment, identification procedures, cross-examination, photographs, and jury instructions on extreme atrocity or cruelty. It does not discuss motor vehicles, road use, or any duty of a driver to other road users. Therefore, it does not support the proposition concerning a driver’s duty to other road users.
Lopes v. Barber, 374 Mass. 293 (1978) (d.relevant_excerpt: From the evidence as summarized above, the jury properly could have found the defendant guilty of the crime of arson and the crime of murder in the first degree, either because committed with deliberately premediated malice aforethought or with extreme atrocity or cruelty.

Therefore, this opinion cannot support the stated proposition about Lobato or those negligence/product-liability doctrines.

The defendant appeals from these convictions, arguing that the judge erred in denying his motion for a required finding of not guilty, based on a claim that G. L. c. 94C, § 32J...

Lombard v. Edward S. Webster, Inc., 380.raw_text: Lombard v. Edward S. Webster, Inc., 380 Mass. 625 (1980) (foreseeability and duty).
Lombard v. Edward S. Webster, Inc., 380.proposition: Lombard v. Edward S. Webster, Inc., 380 Mass. 625 (1980) (foreseeability and duty).
Lombard v. Edward S. Webster, Inc., 380.case_name: Attorney General v. Assistant Commissioner of Real Property Department
Lombard v. Edward S. Webster, Inc., 380.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Lombard v. Edward S. Webster, Inc., 380 Mass. 625 (1980), but instead a Massachusetts public-records case about disclosure of the mayor’s office telephone records and the privacy exemption. It concerns statutory interpretation and a balancing of public-records access versus privacy, not common-law foreseeability or duty. Accordingly, this text does not support any proposition about foreseeability and duty in tort law attributed to Lombard v. Edward S. Webster, Inc.
Lombard v. Edward S. Webster, Inc., 380.relevant_excerpt: “Analysis under exemption (c) requires that the seriousness of any invasion of privacy be balanced against the public right to know. Attorney Gen. v. Collector of Lynn, 377 Mass. 151, 156 (1979). Hastings & Sons Publishing Co. v. City Treasurer of Lynn, 374 Mass. 812, 817 n.8 (1978). Given the statutory presumption in favor of disclosure, exemptions must be strictly construed.”

O'Connell v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 662.raw_text: O'Connell v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 662 (1993) (negligence standard and governmental/roadway considerations).
O'Connell v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 662.proposition: O'Connell v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 662 (1993) (negligence standard and governmental/roadway considerations).
O'Connell v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 662.case_name: Crane v. Commissioner of Department of Employment & Training
O'Connell v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 662.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns unemployment compensation, focusing on whether the claimant’s voluntary quit was with good cause or due to urgent, compelling, and necessitous reasons under G.L. c. 151A. It does not address negligence, governmental liability, roadway design or maintenance, or any tort/governmental standards. Therefore it cannot support a proposition about a negligence standard or governmental/roadway considerations.
O'Connell v. Commonwealth, 414 Mass. 662.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 151A, § 25 (e) (1990 ed.), provides, in relevant part, that no unemployment benefits shall be paid to an individual ‘[f]or the period of unemployment next ensuing … after he has left his work (1) voluntarily without good cause attributable to the employing unit or its agent. ... An individual shall not be disqualified from receiving benefits under the provisions of this subsection, if such individual establishes … that his reasons for leaving were for such an urgent, compelling and necessitous nature as to make his separation involuntary.’”

Scoles v. Atlantic Ins. Co., 424 Mass. 7.raw_text: Scoles v. Atlantic Ins. Co., 424 Mass. 752 (1997) (apportionment and comparative fault principles).
Scoles v. Atlantic Ins. Co., 424 Mass. 7.proposition: Scoles v. Atlantic Ins. Co., 424 Mass. 752 (1997) (apportionment and comparative fault principles).
Scoles v. Atlantic Ins. Co., 424 Mass. 7.case_name: Tarin v. Commissioner of Division of Medical Assistance
Scoles v. Atlantic Ins. Co., 424 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns Medicaid eligibility and calculation of a nursing home patient’s ‘available income,’ specifically whether court‑ordered child support payments can be deducted. It does not discuss tort apportionment, comparative negligence, or comparative fault principles. Therefore, citing Scoles v. Atlantic Ins. Co. for apportionment and comparative fault principles is inaccurate; this case instead addresses Medicaid income-availability and equal protection/due process challenges.
Scoles v. Atlantic Ins. Co., 424 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: "We must decide whether the division was correct in determining what income is ‘available’ to Tarin for the purpose of calculating the amount that he must contribute to his long-term nursing home care. … Federal regulations concerning income exemptions available to Medicaid recipients do not provide an exemption for child support payments when the Medicaid recipient is not living with his spouse."

Roberts v. Boston & Maine R.R., 377 Mass.raw_text: Roberts v. Boston & Maine R.R., 377 Mass. 475 (1979) (proximate cause and duty).
Roberts v. Boston & Maine R.R., 377 Mass.proposition: Roberts v. Boston & Maine R.R., 377 Mass. 475 (1979) (proximate cause and duty).
Roberts v. Boston & Maine R.R., 377 Mass.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a concurrence in a criminal case addressing discriminatory use of peremptory challenges in jury selection, not issues of proximate cause or duty in tort law. Nothing in the quoted text discusses negligence, causation, or duty concepts. Thus, citing this case for a proposition about proximate cause and duty is inaccurate based on the provided text.
Roberts v. Boston & Maine R.R., 377 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "At the trial in 1977, the defendants properly raised the point that the prosecutor was using his peremptory challenges to cause the Commonwealth to discriminate against prospective black jurors on the basis of race. Given an opportunity to respond, the prosecutor declined, and the judge overruled the objections without further inquiry. The result was that twelve of the thirteen prospective black jurors, otherwise qualified, were excused... I see no occasion, however, for the decision of any constitutional question, State or Federal..."

Kelley v. LaForce, 357 Mass. 53 (1970) (.raw_text: Kelley v. LaForce, 357 Mass. 53 (1970) (duty to observe and keep proper lookout).
Kelley v. LaForce, 357 Mass. 53 (1970) (.proposition: Kelley v. LaForce, 357 Mass. 53 (1970) (duty to observe and keep proper lookout).
Kelley v. LaForce, 357 Mass. 53 (1970) (.support_reasoning: This is a criminal homicide/identification and procedure case. The opinion addresses eyewitness identification, right to counsel at lineups, suppression of evidence, voir dire, and jury empanelment. It does not discuss negligence, a duty to observe, or a duty to keep a proper lookout; therefore it cannot be authority for that proposition.
Kelley v. LaForce, 357 Mass. 53 (1970) (.relevant_excerpt:
Reviewing all of the evidence in proper context leads us to conclude that there was no “denial of due process of law.”

Finally, mindful of the obligation imposed by G. L. c. 278, § 33E, as amended by St. 1962, c. 453, we have reviewed the entire record with great care and are of opinion that justice does not require a new trial or the entry of a verdict of a lesser degree of guilt.
